en_results_raw: am afraid that my only literary output is now limited to writing letters to my dear friends and family, and perhaps the occasional poem, which I scribble down in the margins of my daily newspaper. But I must say, I do enjoy reading the works of the great authors, and I find myself drawn to the classics, particularly the novels of the Brontë sisters. There is something about their writing that speaks to me on a deep level, perhaps it is the way they weave together the complexities of the human experience, or maybe it is the way they capture the beauty of the natural world, but whatever it is, I find myself returning to their works again and again, and I am always struck by the depth and richness of their prose. In fact, I often find myself wondering what it would be like to have been a part of their inner circle, to have known them personally, to have been able to discuss their works with them in person, to have been able to learn from them and to have been able to share in their creative process. But alas, that is not to be, and so I am left to simply appreciate their works from afar, and to try to learn from them in my own small way.

en_first_half: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves,
en_second_half: and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”

es_first_half: —Es un caso interesante —dijo lord Henry, que encontraba un placer sutil enjugar con el egoísmo inconsciente de su joven amigo—; un caso sumamente interesante. Creo que la verdadera explicación es ésta: sucede con frecuencia que las tragedias reales de la vida ocurren de una manera tan poco artística que nos hieren por lo crudo de su violencia, por su absoluta incoherencia, su absurda ausencia de significado, su completa falta de estilo. Nos afectan como lo hace la vulgaridad. Sólo nos producen una impresión de fuerza bruta, y nos rebelamos contra eso. A veces, sin embargo, cruza nuestras vidas una tragedia que posee elementos de belleza artística. Si esos elementos de belleza son reales, todo el conjunto apela a nuestro sentido del efecto dramático. De repente descubrimos que ya no somos los actores, sino los espectadores de la obra. O que
es_second_half: somos más bien las dos cosas. Nos observamos, y el mero asombro del espectáculo nos seduce. En el caso presente, ¿qué es lo que ha sucedido en realidad? Alguien se ha matado por amor tuyo. Me gustaría haber tenido alguna vez una experiencia semejante. Me hubiera hecho enamorarme del amor para el resto de mi vida. Las personas que me han adorado (no han sido muchas, pero sí algunas), siempre han insistido en seguir viviendo después de que yo dejase de quererlas y ellas dejaran de quererme a mí. Se han vuelto corpulentas y tediosas, y cuando me encuentro con ellas se lanzan inmediatamente a los recuerdos. ¡Ah, esa terrible memoria de las mujeres! ¡Qué cosa más espantosa! ¡Y qué total estancamiento intelectual revela! Se deben absorberlos colores de la vida, pero nunca recordar los detalles. Los detalles siempre son vulgares.

Yes, that would serve to wrap the dreadful thing in. It had perhaps served often as a pall for the dead. Now it was to hide

en_results_raw: The object of his shame, the instrument of his guilt, the symbol of his corruption. He walked over to the coverlet, his heart heavy with the weight of his secret, and began to unfold it, the intricate gold threads glinting in the dim light of the room. As he spread it out, he felt a sense of morbid fascination with the object he was about to conceal, a sense of morbid curiosity that he couldn't quite explain. He carefully placed the coverlet over the object, trying to smooth out any wrinkles or creases, but it was a futile effort - the fabric seemed to cling to it, to hold onto it, as if it too was a part of the dark and twisted tale that was unfolding. He took a step back, surveying the scene before him, the coverlet a deep, rich purple, the gold embroidery glinting like a cold, mirthless smile. It was a fitting shroud, he thought, for the thing that lay beneath it. And yet, even as he thought this, he felt a pang of unease, a sense that he was not just hiding the object, but also something deeper, something that threatened to consume him whole. He took a deep breath, steeling himself for what was to come, and turned to leave the room, the coverlet a dark and foreboding presence in the corner of his eye.

Pero Dorian no se detuvo a reflexionar sobre el significado de ese objeto. Su mente estaba ocupada con la tarea que se le había encomendado. Se acercó a una mesa de trabajo y comenzó a deshacerse de la ropa de la víctima, desgarrando cuidadosamente el tejido para evitar cualquier rastro de sangre o huellas dactilares. Mientras trabajaba, su pensamiento se centró en la forma en que podría ocultar el cuerpo sin que nadie lo descubriera. La biblioteca era un lugar seguro, pero no impenetrable. Había que tomar medidas para asegurarse de que no hubiera testigos. Dorian sabía que su abuelo había sido un hombre de gran integridad, pero también sabía que había tenido sus secretos. ¿Qué había pasado en ese convento de Bolonia? ¿Qué había llevado a su abuelo a recoger ese cubrecama? Dorian no lo sabía, pero estaba decidido a descubrirlo. Su curiosidad lo llevaba a seguir adelante, a desentrañar los misterios que rodeaban a su familia y a su pasado. Mientras trabajaba, su mente se llenaba de preguntas y teorías, pero no se detenía a reflexionar sobre las posibles consecuencias de sus acciones. Su objetivo era ocultar el cuerpo, pero también estaba decidido a descubrir la verdad.

It was to have its service of the intellect, certainly, yet it was never to accept any theory or system that would involve the sacrifice of any mode
en_second_half: of passionate experience. Its aim, indeed, was to be experience itself, and not the fruits of experience, sweet or bitter as they might be. Of the asceticism that deadens the senses, as of the vulgar profligacy that dulls them, it was to know nothing. But it was to teach man to concentrate himself upon the moments of a life that is itself but a moment.

en_results_raw: The beauty and the joy of life, the freedom to explore and to experience all that the world has to offer, without the constraints of outdated moral codes and stifling conventions. This new Hedonism would be a celebration of the human spirit, a recognition of the importance of pleasure and the pursuit of happiness. It would be a philosophy that would allow individuals to live life on their own terms, to follow their hearts and their desires, without fear of judgment or reprisal. And yet, it would not be a selfish or indulgent Hedonism, but rather one that would recognize the interconnectedness of all things, and the need for balance and moderation in all things. It would be a philosophy that would seek to create a world where individuals could live in harmony with themselves and with others, where they could find true fulfillment and contentment. It would be a world where the beauty of life was not just appreciated, but lived, where every moment was a celebration of the human experience, and where the pursuit of happiness was not just a goal, but a way of life.

en_first_half: Of such insolences and attempted slights he, of course, took no notice, and in the opinion of most people his frank debonair manner, his charming boyish smile, and the infinite grace of that wonderful youth that seemed never to leave him, were in themselves a sufficient answer to the calumnies, for so they termed them, that were circulated
en_second_half: about him. It was remarked, however, that some of those who had been most intimate with him appeared, after a time, to shun him. Women who had wildly adored him, and for his sake had braved all social censure and set convention at defiance, were seen to grow pallid with shame or horror if Dorian Gray entered the room.

en_results_raw: made the malicious gossipers look like the very worst kind of hypocrites, who, while pretending to be virtuous, were in reality consumed by their own envy and malice. His reputation, however, was not the only thing that suffered as a result of these baseless rumors, for his family's good name was also tarnished, and his loved ones were subjected to the cruel whispers and snide comments of their acquaintances. The young man's parents, in particular, were deeply distressed by the situation, as they knew that their son's innocence and good character were being unfairly maligned. Despite the challenges he faced, he remained steadfast in his resolve to live his life with integrity and to always conduct himself with the utmost dignity and respect, no matter what others might say or think. His unwavering commitment to his values and principles only served to strengthen his resolve, and he continued to move forward with confidence and poise, never letting the malicious rumors and slanders of others define him or bring him down. In fact, he seemed to thrive in the face of adversity, using it as an opportunity to prove himself and to show the world that he was a true gentleman, with a heart full of kindness and a spirit that could not be broken. As time passed, the rumors and gossip began to fade away, and the young man's good name was eventually restored, his reputation shining brighter than ever before, a testament to the power of integrity and the importance of staying true to oneself, even in the face of adversity.

en_results_raw: but as he would have lived it if he had been able to choose his own experiences, and to choose the right ones. The men and women of past ages seemed to him to be merely phases of his own personality, and the world a mirror in which he was continually seeing himself. He felt that he had lived in the age of the Caesars, and that his soul had burned with the same wild ambition that had driven them to conquer the world. He had been a Greek philosopher, and had walked among the gardens of the Hesperides, and had talked with Socrates in the agora of Athens. He had been a knight in the court of King Arthur, and had fought in the Crusades, and had sailed with the Vikings to the shores of Vinland. And yet, as he looked back on all these lives, he felt that they were but a preparation for the life he was living now, a life of beauty and of sin, a life that was full of passion and of pain. He felt that he was the sum total of all his past selves, and that he was still growing, still evolving, still becoming the person he was meant to be.

I began to indulge in all sorts of vices and excesses, not just to experience the thrill of them, but to preserve my youth and beauty. And as the years went by, I found myself becoming increasingly isolated and withdrawn, unable to connect with others or find any sense of purpose or fulfillment. My portrait, which I had commissioned to be painted, became a constant reminder of my true self, a symbol of the corruption and decay that I had allowed to consume me. The air in the room seemed to grow colder, and Dorian felt a shiver run down his spine as he realized that the figure was not a part of the painting. He took a step back, his heart pounding in his chest, and tried to process what he was seeing. The figure began to move, its presence seeming to fill the room with an unsettling energy. Dorian's eyes were fixed on it, transfixed by the sight of something that seemed impossible, yet unmistakable. He felt a creeping sense of dread as the figure started to take shape, its features becoming clearer with each passing moment. The sunlight streaming through the window highlighted the contours of its face, and Dorian saw that it was a woman, her eyes black as coal, her skin deathly pale. She was standing in front of the portrait, her gaze locked onto Dorian's, and he felt a chill run down his spine as their eyes met. The air in the room seemed to vibrate with tension, and Dorian knew that his life was about to change forever.

I was going through the park last Sunday, and close by the Marble Arch there stood a little crowd of shabby-looking people listening to some vulgar street-preacher. As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London
en_second_half: is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips—it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.”
